en.paragraph1: In a modern school, teachers spend up to 30% of their time on routine tasks: checking homework, filling out journals and sending out assignments. Students, in turn, often lose deadlines in chat rooms or don't understand why they got this or that grade.
en.paragraph2: This project was born as an answer to these pains - a unified platform for learning management.
en.paragraph3: Formulated a key user challenge that clearly demonstrates the need for the platform, covering all categories of users:
en.paragraph4: Help study participants easily obtain, share, and analyze learning information to make more informed decisions and spend less time on organizational issues.
en.paragraph5: This stage is a test that showed the gap between what people say and what they actually experience.
en.paragraph6: Before reinventing the wheel, I carefully studied the competitors - from Diary.ru to ElJur. I was interested not just in what they do, but why even popular services leave users dissatisfied.
en.paragraph7: Design is not about pretty buttons. It's about understanding the people who will use them. Recreating a portrait of the user - not an abstract ‚ÄúCA‚Äù:
en.paragraph9: When I forget to write down my homework, I want to see it in my journal quickly so I don't get a D for undone work.
en.paragraph10: When I get a bad grade, I want to figure out how to fix it so I can show my parents not only the problem but also the solution.
en.paragraph11: When I have a lot of tasks for the week, I want to see priorities so I can spread the load without stress.
en.paragraph12: When I miss class, I want to get materials and assignments quickly so I don't fall behind in class.
en.paragraph14: When I see a grade below a 4, I want to know right away if and how it can be corrected so I can help the child, not scold them.
en.paragraph15: When I don't have time to check my journal daily, I like to get a once-a-week summary of major events so I can stay informed without too much effort.
en.paragraph16: –öhen a teacher writes a reprimand, I want to understand how serious it is so that I don't panic over nothing.
en.paragraph17: When a child says ‚Äúwe weren't assigned anything,‚Äù I want to check it quickly to avoid arguments and mistrust.
en.paragraph19: When I post grades, I want the system to automatically notify parents so I don't waste time with correspondence.
en.paragraph20: When I prepare a grade report, I want the data to be collected automatically so I can turn it in without nightly vigils.
en.paragraph21: When I see many students getting one topic wrong, I want to quickly create an additional assignment to close the gaps.
en.paragraph22: When parents ask the same questions, I like to give them a link to a ready explanation in the journal so I don't repeat myself.
en.paragraph24: As a student, I want to see my schedule for the week so I can plan my preparation for class.
en.paragraph25: As a student, I want to easily find my homework list so I don't forget to do anything.
en.paragraph26: As a student, I want to see my current grades in all subjects to understand my progress.
en.paragraph28: As a teacher, I want to enter grades into the e-journal quickly to save time.
en.paragraph29: As a teacher, I want to post homework assignments easily so that all students get them on time.
en.paragraph30: As a teacher, I want to send messages to parents through the diary to address issues promptly.
en.paragraph32: As a parent, I want to see my child's grades and comments so I can monitor their progress.
en.paragraph33: As a parent, I want to check the homework list to help my child with their studies.
en.paragraph34: As a parent, I want to be able to write to teachers to address issues that arise.
en.paragraph35: I didn't just draw a beautiful diagram - I walked a virtual path. From the first acquaintance with the platform to daily use.
en.paragraph39: Developed key use case scenarios to show how real-world problems of educational participants are addressed:
en.paragraph40: Designed User Flow to visualize the ideal user journey - without unnecessary steps or frustration:
en.paragraph41: A sitemap was designed to create a logical and predictable structure where each element is in its proper place.
en.paragraph46: I tested it with two real users to check how intuitive the interface is.
en.paragraph47: This project was much more than just a design case study for me. It was a real challenge that taught me some valuable lessons:
en.paragraph48: Simplicity is the key to successful implementation.
en.paragraph49: Testing should be as realistic as possible.
en.paragraph50: Flexibility is more important than perfectionism.
en.paragraph51: Thank you for taking the time to do this work. And by tradition - I'll end with a quote :)
en.paragraph52: ¬´Good design is like air: you don't notice it while it's there. But once it's gone, you realize how important it was¬ª
